For this pilot's widow, Sarkozy's Libyan funding case is personal
subhead: The 1989 bombing of UTA Flight 772, ordered by the Libyan regime of Muammar Gaddafi, robbed Maryvone Raveneau of her husband. As a plaintiff in the trial of Nicolas Sarkozy, who is accused of having struck a deal with Gaddafi, she has been disappointed by the media battle waged by the former French president and his supporters.

title: US national security strategy targets Europe and spares adversaries
In Jerusalem, Merz reaffirms Germany's support for Israel
Asma Mhalla, political scientist: 'Peter Thiel embeds AI in a worldview where conflict and the state of emergency become virtues'
subhead: As American tech billionaire Peter Thiel criticizes a global order that stifles progress, he and other Silicon Valley players are looking to replace it with a technological totalitarianism that Europe must reject, argues researcher Asma Mhalla.

title: In India, a fire at a popular Goa nightclub kills at least 23
subhead: The deadly blaze broke out around midnight at a club in Arpora, in North Goa district. Officials will conduct fire safety audits at similar venues to prevent similar incidents from occurring.

title: When Christmas presents are secondhand: 'My sisters looked at me strangely'
subhead: Far from consumerist extravaganzas like 'Black Friday' or 'Cyber Monday,' some people in France prefer to turn to secondhand and recycled goods for their holiday shopping. Juggling the risks of technical failure and the fear of being seen as 'cheapskates,' they share their experiences.

title: 2026 World Cup excites Atlanta's business community: 'A generational opportunity'
subhead: The capital of Georgia, which hosted the 1996 Olympic Games, is set to welcome eight matches during the upcoming World Cup. For local business leaders, the event is first and foremost an opportunity to do business.
byline: By Nicolas Chapuis (Atlanta (United States), special correspondent)

title: Belgium resists unfreezing Russian assets held in Brussels
subhead: Prime Minister Bart De Wever voiced concerns over the legal, financial and security repercussions of what he described as a potential 'theft' of Russian assets.

title: Germany introduces voluntary military service
subhead: Fourteen years after suspending mandatory military service, Germany plans to offer 18-year-olds the opportunity to undertake a voluntary military service lasting at least six months, with a monthly salary of €2,600.

title: War in Ukraine: Europe finds itself sidelined and humiliated by the Trump administration
subhead: Steve Witkoff, the US president's special envoy, and Jared Kushner, Donald Trump's son-in-law, chose to meet the Ukrainian negotiators in Miami after canceling their Brussels stopover on their return from Moscow.
